intro: Leucopogon hirtellus, commonly known as the hairy leucopogon, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, commonly known as the heath family, and is characterized by its erect, shrub-like growth habit. The plant produces small, white or pink flowers that are clustered in umbels, which are typically borne on the upper part of the stems. Its leaves are simple, alternate, and covered with fine hairs, contributing to its common name. Leucopogon hirtellus is adapted to acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland or rocky habitats.
